recordings.file-name: XC676107-S49F3M1 odd owl or something else.mp3
recordings.rmk:
Nomig recording from garden. Telinga Stereo Mk2 and parabola. 500 Hz high pass filter.

Initially dismissed as female Tawny Owl (Strix Aluco) as they are always vocal through the night here and make a variety of calls. But then realized likely to be Northern Lapwing (Vanellus vanellus) (aka Peewit).

Would be grateful for confirmation as novice nocmigger.

EDIT: Now resolved as Northern Lapwing.

Recorded:

  • song, chaaew-á-á-o-wee ayhrre-willuch-o-weep

General observations: Open fields, close to an overgrown lake. Two lapwings in display-flight. Mostly sunny. Temperature: 1°C/33.8 °F. Northerly wind, light breeze.

Sound classification and rendering: NatureGuides, 2020, Birds of Western Palearctic, AppStore.

Recording equipment: Dodotronic Hi-sound Stereo AOL Parabolic Microphone, Olympus LS-P4 Recorder

recordings.loc: Akcja Siemianowka Bird Ringing Station (near Siemianowka), Podlaskie Voivodeship
recordings.rmk: Recorded with Wildlife Acoustics SM4. Recorded in shrubs between forest and wetland.
Recorded flying around the West Scrape using a Tascam DR-05X recorder.

Intensive alarm  calls of several *Vanellus vanellus* individuals during a putative nocturnal egg predation event. Prior to the focal night there were eight clutches on a extensively managed meadow of which just two were still incubated at the next survey two days after the recording. (Extract of continous recording using a Olympus VN-713 PC audio recorder)

recordings.loc: Södra Utmossen at Lenstad village, Öland
recordings.rmk:
Recorded with my ZOOM H5 Handy Recorder. High Pass Filter applied with Audacity

Walking to the swamp and the birds started to fly around. So this is the reason for me to put it as an ALARM CALL.

But this is the sound I heard the Northern Lapwing did all over Öland and they are also one of the reason that it is so hard to get close to other birds for pictures as the lapwing alarm all the birds

Calls from birds standing at and flying over a field close to the lake. Dark night.

Recorded on a clear day while the bird was foraging on a stretch of grassland near a water body in its winter habitat in North-east India. There were bar-headed geese and grey lag geese in the same area. The bar-headed geese were also foraging in the same location. There is an overhead flying rose ringed parakeet also.
